facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 119 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 119 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated June 16, 1953 of Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 1 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 16, 1953, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 24, 1958 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. November 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: Appellant is a company carrying on business as distiller of country liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany carrying on business as a distiller of companyntry liquor.

facts.text: Appellant incorporated in May 1945 as reconstruction of previously existing Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. under Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was incorporated in May 1945 and was in fact a previously existing companypany called the Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. reconstructed under the provisions of the Companys Act.

facts.text: Appellant carried on same business as predecessor: sale of distillery produce to licensed wholesalers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant carried on the same business as its predecessor, namely, sale of the produce of its distillery to licensed wholesalers.

facts.text: Wholesalers sold liquor to licensed retailers, who sold to consumers.

anchor.surface_text: The wholesalers in their turn sold the liquor to licensed retailers from whom the actual companysumers made their purchases.

facts.text: Entire trade controlled by Government regulations.

anchor.surface_text: The entire trade was largely companytrolled by Government regulations.

facts.text: After war started, demand for country liquor increased but bottle scarcity.

anchor.surface_text: After the war started the demand for companyntry liquor increased but difficulty was felt in finding bottles in which the liquor was to be sold.

facts.text: Government devised buy-back scheme in 1940 to relieve bottle scarcity.

anchor.surface_text: In order to relieve the scarcity of bottles the Government devised in 1940 a scheme called the buy-back scheme.

facts.text: Buy-back scheme: distiller charges wholesaler fixed price for bottles, repayable on return.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme in substance was that a distiller on a sale of liquor became entitled to charge a wholesaler a price for the bottles in which the liquor was supplied at rates fixed by the Government which he was bound to repay to the wholesaler on the latter returning the bottles.

facts.text: Similar arrangement for wholesaler to retailer and retailer to consumer at different rates.

anchor.surface_text: The same arrangement, but with prices calculated at different rates was made for the liquor sold in bottles by a wholesaler to a retailer and by a retailer to the companysumers.

facts.text: In 1944, Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. insisted on additional security deposits from wholesalers per bottle, promising refund on return and full on 90% return.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1944, the Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. which then was in existence, insisted on the wholesalers paying to it in addition to the price of the bottles fixed under the buy-back scheme, certain amounts described as security deposits and calculated at varying rates per bottle according to sizes for the bottles in which the liquor was supplied to them promising to pay back for each bottle returned at the rate applicable to it and further promising to pay back the entire amount paid on a transaction when 90 per cent. of the bottles companyered by it had been returned.

facts.text: Appellant realized these additional sums after taking over business.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany while it was in existence realised these additional sums and so did the appellant after it took over the business.

facts.text: Object of additional sums: inducement for bottle return to avoid hampering trade.

anchor.surface_text: The object of demanding and taking these additional sums was obviously to provide additional inducement for the return of the bottles to the distiller so that its trade in selling the produce of its distillery might number be hampered for want of bottles.

facts.text: No time limit for bottle return to get refund; no refund ever refused.

anchor.surface_text: No time limit had been fixed within which the bottles had to be returned in order to entitle a wholesaler to the refund, number does it appear that a refund had ever been refused.

facts.text: Buy-back price entered in general trading account; additional sums in Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit Account.

anchor.surface_text: The price of the bottles received by the appellant under the buy-back scheme was entered by it in its general trading account while the additional sum received for them was entered in the general ledger under the heading Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit Account .

facts.text: Additional amounts taken without Government's sanction, as condition imposed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that for the accounting periods with which this case is companycerned, the additional amounts had been taken without Governments sanction and entirely as a companydition imposed by the appellant itself for the sale of its liquor.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to income-tax on balance of additional sums after refunds.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was assessed to income-tax on the balance of the amounts of these additional sums left after the refunds made there out.

facts.text: Assessed to business profits tax and excess profits tax on same balance.

anchor.surface_text: It had also been assessed to business profits tax and excess profits tax on the same balance.

facts.text: Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: Its appeals against the orders of assessment to these taxes to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and thereafter to the Tribunal failed.

facts.text: Reference to Punjab High Court on question whether security deposits assessable under section 10 of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It then obtained an order referring a certain question arising out of the assessments for decision by the High Court of Punjab. The question originally suggested was reframed and in its final form reads thus Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the companylections by the assessee companypany described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Punjab High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court against High Court decision on all three taxes.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against that decision which related to all the three varieties of taxes for which the appellant had been made liable.

facts.text: Security deposits returned when 90% bottles covered returned.

anchor.surface_text: the entire sum taken in one transaction was refunded when 90 per cent. of the bottles companyered by it had been returned, though the remaining 10 per cent. had number been returned.

facts.text: No obligation on wholesalers to return bottles.

anchor.surface_text: The wholesalers were clearly under numberobligation to return the bottles.

under section 10 of the Income-tax Act? The High Court answered the question in the affirmative. The present appeal is against that decision which related to all the three varieties of taxes for which the appellant had been made liable. We are concerned in this appeal only with the additional sums demanded and received by the appellant and described as security deposit and not with the price of bottles which also it took under government sanction.

concepts.interpretation: The collections described as empty bottle return security deposits were trading receipts and therefore income assessable under section 10.

What the partners did in this case, as I have said, was to decide among themselves that what they had previously regarded as a liability of the firm they would not, for practical reasons, regard as a liability but that does not mean that at that moment they received something,

concepts.interpretation: The nature of a receipt as trading receipt or otherwise is determined at the time of receipt and cannot change later by accounting entries or decisions.

The question is whether these amounts called security deposits were trading receipts.

It had also been assessed to business profits tax and excess profits tax on the same balance. Its appeals against the orders of assessment to these taxes to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and thereafter to the Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: It was incorporated in May 1945 and was in fact a previously existing company called the Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. reconstructed under the provisions of the Companies Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

issues.text: whether these amounts called security deposits were trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether these amounts called security deposits were trading receipts. Now, as already stated, the appellants trade consisted in selling in bottles liquor produced in its distillery to wholesalers.

issues.text: whether the additional sums were part of the price or consideration for the sale of bottled liquor

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Vishwanatha Sastri appearing on behalf of the appellant first contended that on these facts the amounts could not be regarded as price and that therefore they were not trading receipts. He said that the price of the bottles was separately fixed and the amount taken as deposit was different from and exclusive of, it.

issues.text: whether the additional sums were security deposits securing the return of the bottles

anchor.surface_text: Now, if these additional sums were not part of the price, what were they? Mr. Sastri said that they were deposits securing the return of the bottles. According to him if they were such security deposits, they were not trading receipts. Again we are unable to agree.

issues.text: whether the additional sums were borrowed money or loans

anchor.surface_text: We hold accordingly that the sums received during this period cannot be regarded as borrowed money. It seems to us that the amounts involved in the present case were exactly of the nature of the deposits made in the second period in Lakshmanier Sons case.

issues.text: whether the quality and nature of the receipt is fixed at the time it is received

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received. What the partners did in this case, as I have said, was to decide among themselves that what they had previously regarded as a liability of the firm they would not, for practical reasons, regard as a liability but that does not mean that at that moment they received something,

arguments.claim: The additional sums could not be regarded as price because the price of the bottles was separately fixed under the buy-back scheme and the deposit amount was different from and exclusive of it, therefore not trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Vishwanatha Sastri appearing on behalf of the appellant first contended that on these facts the amounts could not be regarded as price and that therefore they were not trading receipts. He said that the price of the bottles was separately fixed and the amount taken as deposit was different from and exclusive of, it. This contention is founded on the use of the word price in the buy-back scheme

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eturned as and when the bottles were returned. The moneys described as security deposit were also returned as and when the bottles were returned with

arguments.court_reasoning: Undue emphasis on word 'price'; all sums part of consideration for sale of bottled liquor as sale would not occur without them

arguments.claim: The additional sums were part of the consideration for the sale of bottled liquor and therefore part of the price and trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that this contention lays undue emphasis on that word. We think that the High Court took substantially a correct view of the matter when it said that in realising these amounts the company was really charging an extra price for the bottles . It is clear to us that the trade consisted of sale of bottled liquor and the consideration for the sale was constituted by several amounts respectively called, the price of the liquor, the price of the bottles and the security deposit.

arguments.claim: The additional sums were deposits securing the return of the bottles and therefore not trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: Now, if these additional sums were not part of the price, what were they? Mr. Sastri said that they were deposits securing the return of the bottles. According to him if they were such security deposits, they were not trading receipts. Again we are unable to agree.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d in a separate ledger termed empty bottles return deposit account , for, what was a companysideration for the sale cannot cease to be so by being wri

arguments.court_reasoning: No obligation on wholesalers to return bottles; words 'security deposit' alone insufficient to create obligation; no time limit for return

arguments.claim: High Court correctly held that realising these amounts was charging an extra price for the bottles

anchor.surface_text: We think that the High Court took substantially a correct view of the matter when it said that in realising these amounts the company was really charging an extra price for the bottles .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eturned as and when the bottles were returned with only this difference that in this case the entire sum taken in one transaction was refunded when 90

arguments.claim: Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd. applies; deposits were not trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: For this part of the case Mr. Sastri relied on Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd. , but we do not think that case assists at all. What had happened there was that the Shell Company had appointed a large number of agents in China to sell its products and had taken from each agent a deposit to secure itself against the risk of default by the agent duly to account for the sale proceeds.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e risk of default by the agent duly to PI account for the sale proceeds. The deposits were made in Chinese dollars and later companyverted into sterli

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished; Shell deposits anterior to trading transactions and part of trading structure; here amounts part of each trading transaction

arguments.claim: Even if amounts were security deposits for return of bottles, they would still be trading receipts as part of trading transactions

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanyal was prepared to argue that even if the amounts were securities deposited for the return of the bottles, they would still be trading receipts, for they were part of the trading transactions and the return of the bottles was necessary to enable the appellant to carry on its trade

court_response_anchor.surface_text: g good the agents defaults in the event of any de

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to pronounce as already held not security deposits

arguments.claim: Amounts analogous to deposits in second period of K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons case and thus trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: The case nearest to the present one is, in our view, that decided by this Court in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax... Under the second part... partake more of the nature of trading receipts than of security deposits... We hold accordingly that the sums received during this period cannot be regarded as borrowed money

arguments.claim: Present case falls within third period arrangement in Lakshmanier Sons case where deposits were loans

anchor.surface_text: It was Mr. Sastris effort to bring the case within the arrangement that prevailed in the third part of the accounting period in Lakshmanier Sons case, the initial payments made during which were held to be loans.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ely, a companytract deposit account and a current yarn account, crediting the moneys received from the customers in the former account and transferrin

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished; third period deposit fixed once for business connection with interest, unrelated to specific contracts; here per transaction, part of price

arguments.claim: Amounts in Morley v. Tattersall were not income; similarly here amounts not income

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri also referred us to Morley v. Pattersall and contended that the amounts with which we are concerned, were of the same kind as those considered in that case and were not income.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anier Sons case  1 . There, as here, as soon as a transaction of sale was made the seller received certain moneys in respect of it. It is true that in

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished; Tattersall amounts never trading receipts or appellant's money (client's money creating liability); here appellant's money with profit-making quality

arguments.claim: The quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received. What the partners did in this case, as I have said, was to decide among themselves that what they had previously regarded as a liability of the firm they would not, for practical reasons, regard as a liability

arguments.claim: The collections described as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act? The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: learned Chief Justice further said at p. 1064 The fact that one of the companyditions is that it is to be adjusted against a claim arising out of a po

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court; amounts are trading receipts

arguments.claim: The amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income assessable to tax

anchor.surface_text: Having given the matter our anxious consideration which the difficulties involved in it require, we think that the correct view to take is that the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.

holdings.text: The amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Having given the matter our anxious consideration which the difficulties involved in it require, we think that the correct view to take is that the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amounts integral to sale of bottled liquor as condition for sale, entered trade, possess profit-making quality; distinguished from loans/security by lack of obligation and transaction-specific nature; analogous to Lakshmanier Sons second period deposits.

holdings.text: The amount which was called security deposit was actually a part of the consideration for the sale and therefore part of the price of what was sold.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that this contention lays undue emphasis on that word. We think that the High Court took substantially a correct view of the matter when it said that in realising these amounts the company was really charging an extra price for the bottles . It is clear to us that the trade consisted of sale of bottled liquor and the consideration for the sale was constituted by several amounts respectively called, the price of the liquor, the price of the bottles and the security deposit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All sums (liquor price, bottle price, deposit) required for sale to occur; accounting entries irrelevant; refund mechanism does not alter consideration status.

holdings.text: The wholesalers were clearly under no obligation to return the bottles; words 'security deposit' alone insufficient to create obligation.

anchor.surface_text: Again we are unable to agree. There could be no security given for the return of the bottles unless there was a right to their return for if there was no such right, there would be nothing to secure. Now we find no trace of such a right in the statement of the case. The wholesalers were clearly under no obligation to return the bottles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express right or obligation to return bottles; no time limit for refund; bottles sold outright, buy-back voluntary.

holdings.text: We must therefore on the authority of Lakshmanier Sons case, hold the amounts in the present case to have been trading receipts; cannot be regarded as borrowed money.

anchor.surface_text: The case nearest to the present one is, in our view, that decided by this Court in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax... We hold accordingly that the sums received during this period cannot be regarded as borrowed money. It seems to us that the amounts involved in the present case were exactly of the nature of the deposits made in the second period in Lakshmanier Sons case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transaction-specific payments related to sale price, refundable on bottle return; matches second period in Lakshmanier (advance/adjustment in trade), not third (fixed ongoing deposit with interest).

holdings.text: The quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received. What the partners did in this case, as I have said, was to decide among themselves that what they had previously regarded as a liability of the firm they would not, for practical reasons, regard as a liability but that does not mean that at that moment they received something,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approved from Tattersall; here receipts trading at inception, later decisions cannot alter; unlike Tattersall where never trading receipts (client funds).

holdings.text: The decision applies to income-tax, business profits tax and excess profits tax assessments on the balance of additional sums.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against that decision which related to all the three varieties of taxes for which the appellant had been made liable. We are concerned in this appeal only with the additional sums demanded and received by the appellant and described as security deposit and not with the price of bottles which also it took under government sanction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal against High Court decision on all three taxes; amounts taxable under each as trading receipts/business income.

precedents.cited_proposition: Contract deposits or advances taken at time of sale/contract and refunded after delivery/return of goods are trading receipts not security deposits or loans.

precedents.cited_holding: the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court decision affirmed that the empty bottle return security deposits are trading receipts assessable to tax under section 10 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Having given the matter our anxious consideration which the difficulties involved in it require, we think that the correct view to take is that the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that this contention lays undue emphasis on that word. We think that the High Court took substantially a correct view of the matter when it said that in realising these amounts the company was really charging an extra price for the bottles . It is clear to us that the trade consisted of sale of bottled liquor and the consideration for the sale was constituted by several amounts respectively called, the price of the liquor, the price of the bottles and the security deposit.

anchor.surface_text: Again we are unable to agree. There could be no security given for the return of the bottles unless there was a right to their return for if there was no such right, there would be nothing to secure. Now we find no trace of such a right in the statement of the case. The wholesalers were clearly under no obligation to return the bottles.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The case nearest to the present one is, in our view, that decided by this Court in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax... We hold accordingly that the sums received during this period cannot be regarded as borrowed money. It seems to us that the amounts involved in the present case were exactly of the nature of the deposits made in the second period in Lakshmanier Sons case.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received. What the partners did in this case, as I have said, was to decide among themselves that what they had previously regarded as a liability of the firm they would not, for practical reasons, regard as a liability but that does not mean that at that moment they received something,
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed.
